--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Ron Jeffries <ronjeffries@X...> wrote:
> On Tuesday, November 4, 2003, at 1:44:42 PM, Dave Astels wrote:
> 
> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "ljb114ca" <ljb114ca@y...> wrote:
> >> Can some give me a liitle suggestions how to solve the Eight 
> >> Queens problem with TDD method?
> 
> > Why?  There's well documented solutions.  Look it up.
> 
> > I had a short discussion with <I forget> at OOPSLA last week about
> > the recurring questions of "how would I evolve <insert well known
> > algorithm here> using TDD".  Well.. you don't have to... it's well
> > known.. just use it.  Write a few tests to make sure you have it 
> > typed in correctly and that it keeps working.. but I see no reason
> > to evolve algorithms I learned in University from a text.
> 
> Might be good exercise, though.

Possibly.  But very artificial.  The point is will I try to test-drive
a search or sort algorithm?  Not likely... I'll use one with a
complexity/efficiency to match the expected use (simplest thing that
could work).

I've never found artificial problems to be overly enlightening.

Test-driving card games is fun... start with a simple one like War,
and move up.

Dave
